channel.title: A winterlove style runescape
channel.description:
Just a theoretical question, but could a game like RuneScape, packed full of content, run as fast and as stable as it is if it were set up like a generic winterlove server?
To reiterate, winterlove servers generally have everything packed into one file(client.java).
I'm not talking about the way that winterlove's engine runs, I'm talking if jagex could have packed it all into one class for the most part.
I've wondered this for like a week or two. I don't know if it could because I put shit all over the place(probably too much)

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:13, topic:545007”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663886.msg4437565#msg4437565 date=1405578079]
and you’re also missing the point, by doing that you’re changing the code lol. im talking about taking existing code and just changing how its structured
[/quote]
That wouldn’t be changing the design. Changing the same code around isn’t re-designing it…

This is a design:
[ img]http://figures.oreilly.com/httpatomoreillycomsourceoreillybooks200648I_book_tt2/figs/I_mediaobject1_tt33-web.png[/img][/quote]

"To reiterate, winterlove servers generally have everything packed into one file(client.java).

I’m not talking about the way that winterlove’s engine runs, I’m talking if jagex could have packed it all into one class for the most part."

he’s literally just saying, combining all the classes together… You’d just have one huge class file

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:13, topic:545007”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663886.msg4437565#msg4437565 date=1405578079]
and you’re also missing the point, by doing that you’re changing the code lol. im talking about taking existing code and just changing how its structured
[/quote]
That wouldn’t be changing the design. Changing the same code around isn’t re-designing it…

This is a design:
[/quote]
we aren’t talking about that

op asked if packing everything into one file will reduce the performance of a server and the answer is no. if you have a deltascape server and take everything redundant out of the client class, then put it in its own class will the server magically perform better?

maybe ‘design’ wasn’t the right word to use but the main point doesn’t change

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

lare69:

and you’re also missing the point, by doing that you’re changing the code lol. im talking about taking existing code and just changing how its structured

That wouldn’t be changing the design. Changing the same code around isn’t re-designing it…

This is a design:

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:8, topic:545007”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663886.msg4437489#msg4437489 date=1405560223]

design has nothing to do with performance

… yes it does

The fallacy that different design patterns have no direct impact on application performance is really common sense. If you take a moment to think about it, a program with a complex design pattern will more than likely have to invoke a multitude amount of subroutines, as to where a more simple design has all the data more closely present. Note that this is NOT the only way a more advanced pattern can effect a program. Often a more complex design pattern is chosen for the sake of future expansion, in which case a minor performance loss is offered in return.

A small example of this would be the infamous FizzBuzz problem, take a look at these two solutions…
https://github.com/EnterpriseQualityCoding/FizzBuzzEnterpriseEdition/
http://pastebin.com/qpCuSWVu

In the end it all depends on what you want to accomplish, sometimes cramming everything one a single file is the most logical thing to do and other times it would be to expand it upon hundreds of files. In this particular situation the latter would be most desirable.

wait so you’re saying that if I take the exact same code and just structure it differently you’ll see a noticeable difference in performance?

just can’t see the logic behind that, I mean if you bake a cake and then turn it upside down or put all of the icing in the middle instead of on the top its still going to taste like cake
[/quote]
Would one do you think would have better performance when the execute command holds over 2000 lines or various code from the Java API? I mean, they all do the same thing, so why should the performance be different?

1: while a boolean running is true, a method execute is called only if the difference between the started time and the system’s current time is greater than or equal to 1000 milliseconds.

long startLogMillis = System.currentTimeMillis();
while (running) {
	if (System.currentTimeMillis() - startLogMillis >= 1000) {
		execute();
	}
}

2: while a boolean running is true, a method execute is called and the current thread is paused for 1000 milliseconds.

while (running) {
	execute();
	Thread.sleep(1000);
}

3: A separated thread is scheduled at a fixed rate which will call for the method execute every 1000 milliseconds.

(ScheduledExecutorService).scheduleAtFixedRate(new Runnable() {
	@Override
	public void run() {
		execute();
	}
}, 1000, 1000, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);

Your performance will always depend on your design.[/quote]

-Nothing:

Who the fuck would do this?

this

and you’re also missing the point, by doing that you’re changing the code lol. im talking about taking existing code and just changing how its structured

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:8, topic:545007”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663886.msg4437489#msg4437489 date=1405560223]

design has nothing to do with performance

… yes it does

The fallacy that different design patterns have no direct impact on application performance is really common sense. If you take a moment to think about it, a program with a complex design pattern will more than likely have to invoke a multitude amount of subroutines, as to where a more simple design has all the data more closely present. Note that this is NOT the only way a more advanced pattern can effect a program. Often a more complex design pattern is chosen for the sake of future expansion, in which case a minor performance loss is offered in return.

A small example of this would be the infamous FizzBuzz problem, take a look at these two solutions…
https://github.com/EnterpriseQualityCoding/FizzBuzzEnterpriseEdition/
http://pastebin.com/qpCuSWVu

In the end it all depends on what you want to accomplish, sometimes cramming everything one a single file is the most logical thing to do and other times it would be to expand it upon hundreds of files. In this particular situation the latter would be most desirable.

wait so you’re saying that if I take the exact same code and just structure it differently you’ll see a noticeable difference in performance?

just can’t see the logic behind that, I mean if you bake a cake and then turn it upside down or put all of the icing in the middle instead of on the top its still going to taste like cake
[/quote]
Would one do you think would have better performance when the execute command holds over 2000 lines or various code from the Java API? I mean, they all do the same thing, so why should the performance be different?

1: while a boolean running is true, a method execute is called only if the difference between the started time and the system’s current time is greater than or equal to 1000 milliseconds.

long startLogMillis = System.currentTimeMillis(); while (running) { if (System.currentTimeMillis() - startLogMillis >= 1000) { execute(); } } [/quote]
Who the fuck would do this?

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

imthenull:

If you take a moment to think about it, a program with a complex design pattern will more than likely have to invoke a multitude amount of subroutines, as to where a more simple design has all the data more closely present.

While you sort of have a point - Java method call overhead is negligible. Very fast. It can optimise them out almost certainly better than you can, where possible, and even when it can’t, the penalty isn’t worth thinking about really.

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“lare69, post:4, topic:545007”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=663886.msg4437458#msg4437458 date=1405555074]

design has nothing to do with performance

… yes it does

The fallacy that different design patterns have no direct impact on application performance is really common sense. If you take a moment to think about it, a program with a complex design pattern will more than likely have to invoke a multitude amount of subroutines, as to where a more simple design has all the data more closely present. Note that this is NOT the only way a more advanced pattern can effect a program. Often a more complex design pattern is chosen for the sake of future expansion, in which case a minor performance loss is offered in return.

A small example of this would be the infamous FizzBuzz problem, take a look at these two solutions…
https://github.com/EnterpriseQualityCoding/FizzBuzzEnterpriseEdition/
http://pastebin.com/qpCuSWVu

In the end it all depends on what you want to accomplish, sometimes cramming everything one a single file is the most logical thing to do and other times it would be to expand it upon hundreds of files. In this particular situation the latter would be most desirable.
[/quote]
wait so you’re saying that if I take the exact same code and just structure it differently you’ll see a noticeable difference in performance?

just can’t see the logic behind that, I mean if you bake a cake and then turn it upside down or put all of the icing in the middle instead of on the top its still going to taste like cake[/quote]
Would one do you think would have better performance when the execute command holds over 2000 lines or various code from the Java API? I mean, they all do the same thing, so why should the performance be different?

1: while a boolean running is true, a method execute is called only if the difference between the started time and the system’s current time is greater than or equal to 1000 milliseconds.

long startLogMillis = System.currentTimeMillis();
while (running) {
	if (System.currentTimeMillis() - startLogMillis >= 1000) {
		execute();
	}
}

2: while a boolean running is true, a method execute is called and the current thread is paused for 1000 milliseconds.

while (running) {
	execute();
	Thread.sleep(1000);
}

3: A separated thread is scheduled at a fixed rate which will call for the method execute every 1000 milliseconds.

(ScheduledExecutorService).scheduleAtFixedRate(new Runnable() {
	@Override
	public void run() {
		execute();
	}
}, 1000, 1000, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);

Your performance will always depend on your design.

Read full topic

item.title: A winterlove style runescape
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:6, topic:545007”]Pretty sure more objects would just contribute to server load. There’s also a limit to the amount of characters per java source file.

[quote author=lare69 link=topic=663886.msg4437450#msg4437450 date=1405553505]
design has nothing to do with performance, so yeah it would run fine but would be almost impossible to maintain
[/quote]This, somewhat.

Said performance can probably be achieved.
It would be very hard to maintain.

OP FOR THE LOVE OF GOD PLS DONT.[/quote]
Lol.

I know how hard it would be to maintain(maybe not on that scale). Every delta source I’ve used had everything packed into the client.java.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

lare69:

design has nothing to do with performance

… yes it does

The fallacy that different design patterns have no direct impact on application performance is really common sense. If you take a moment to think about it, a program with a complex design pattern will more than likely have to invoke a multitude amount of subroutines, as to where a more simple design has all the data more closely present. Note that this is NOT the only way a more advanced pattern can effect a program. Often a more complex design pattern is chosen for the sake of future expansion, in which case a minor performance loss is offered in return.

A small example of this would be the infamous FizzBuzz problem, take a look at these two solutions…
